column4: is there a way that I can see my chat history here for ubuntu channel?
http://irclogs.ubuntu.com/
I am there but how do I locate which file to view coz there is no file named #ubuntu only
there is. http://irclogs.ubuntu.com/2012/09/21/%23ubuntu.html
I got it thanks
this internet address i posted cntains a calendar date in reverse notation.

I got it thanks. The one question I ask and am confused quite often is for example I am installing abs-guide now coz I need it now but in a few days i wont and then how do I know what programs I have installed already on my laptop and also what did I install something for
there is software-center which can tell you what's already installed, sorted into categories. there's also synaptic and a couple other package managers which could tell.
to get a full list of all installed packages, run "dpkg -l" in a terminal window. to inspect previously installed packages, look at /var/log/apt/history.log
sofware-centre , If I understand correctly only tells me about the gui packages installed. I am looking for the non gui ones . Also is !apt  a command ?

if you type !apt here in the chat alone on a single line, then ubottu, the friendly channel bot, will consider this a command and respond to it. it is not a common command on ubuntu's command line interface, i.e. the linux shell, though.
alos I installed abs-guide but how do I run it on the cmd
this is a book, i don't think it is meant ot be 'run'.
run "dpkg -L abs-guide" to get a list of all files which were placed on your computer when this package was installed
I meant that if it is a book how do I go through it like a tutorial or something

i have not used it before, but based on the files it contains, which are mostly html and shell skript files in an 'examples' subdirectory, you seem to be supposed to point your web browser to file:///usr/share/doc/abs-guide/html/ to get started

have fun learning shell skripting. if i was to recommend adidtional resources, i'd point you to #bash here on freenode as well as well as the bash related pages on this wiki http://mywiki.wooledge.org/ (a great resource)
thanks
unless: You're both welcome. ;-)

so after I finish learning shell script and cron jobs I am still not sure if I will be able to set up a backup rsync system where if it does not run at a specific time it pops up an error whenever I next switch on the system or sth
you will also need to read the rsync man page, and possibly something on how you make such messages pop up. but besides that, you may well be able to do so by then.
